dc:description:
*ABCB6* was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant isolated microphthalmia with coloboma in 2012 (Wang et al., PMID: 22226084). At least three missense variants have been reported in humans. Evidence supporting this gene disease relationship includes case-level data, segregation data, and experimental data. 

Variants in *ABCB6* have been reported in individuals with the following disease entities: Dyschromatosis universalis hereditaria, Isolated microphthalmia with coloboma, and Familial pseudohyperkalemia. Further, biallelic truncating variants affecting *ABCB6* are responsible for the Lan(-) blood group (MIM#111600). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found differences in phenotypic variability and no consistent mechanism of disease. Therefore, the following disease entities have been split and curated separately: Dyschromatosis universalis hereditaria (MIM#615402), Isolated microphthalmia with coloboma (MIM#614497). Familial pseudohyperkalemia (MIM#609153) has not been curated at this time as it is an asymptomatic condition apparent only in refrigerated blood samples due to temperature-dependent leak of potassium across the cell membrane of erythrocytes. 

Three missense variants in *ABCB6* have been reported in association with isolated microphthalmia with coloboma in three probands across two publications (PMID: 22226084; 24281366). Co-segregation with disease was observed in one family (PMID: 22226084). The mechanism of disease is currently unknown. This gene-disease relationship is supported by a zebrafish model (PMID: 22226084). In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen General Inborn Errors of Metabolism GCEP on 22MAR2024 (SOP 10).

evidence.dc:description: The authors used an ABCB6 morpholino in zebrafish and found that they developed a coloboma phenotype. Injection with wt ABCB6 was sufficient to rescue this phenotype; however, a construct carrying the p.Leu811Val variant was unable to rescue (Fig. 4).
AF = 0.001301 in the South Asian population in gnomAD, with 118 carriers and 2 homozygotes. Therefore, this variant has not been scored, as it is too common to be causal

The authors used an ABCB6 morpholino in zebrafish and found that they developed a coloboma phenotype. Injection with wt ABCB6 was sufficient to rescue this phenotype; however, a construct carrying the p.Ala57Thr variant was unable to rescue (Fig. 4).
Over 6800 het. carriers and 20 homozygotes in gnomAD --> too common to be causal
SNP mapping identified the critical region of 2q35. All 76 genes within this region were Sanger sequenced (all exons and exon/intron boundaries).
evidence.rdfs:label: Wang 2012 - Family 1

member.rdfs:label: Wang 2012 - II:5
member.detectionMethod: SNP mapping identified the critical region of 2q35. All 76 genes within this region were Sanger sequenced (all exons and exon/intron boundaries).

evidence.dc:description: Score reduced because LoF is not established as the mechanism of disease for coloboma (gnomAD pLI = 0, with numerous het. carriers of null alleles). Further, a second group performed similar experiments in morphant zebrafish and found no evidence of coloboma (PMID: 24498303)
The primary phenotype observed in humans is coloboma of the iris, which was recapitulated in morphant zebrafish in this paper.
evidence.rdfs:label: ABCB6 Coloboma zebrafish
